body.p: Richard Whittington says at the last term of the Caldwell Circuit Court a Judgment was rendered against him in behalf of the Commonwealth on an indictment for permitting gaming in his house for the sum of two hundred dollars, the ^Judgt^ was by confession and he now says, that on one occasion he did at the instance of certain friends permit games at his house, in which there was only small amounts bet and the same was mainly for amusement as he understood it, and that is the only occasion in which he has ever voluntarily permitted unlawful gaming in his house.
Sworn to before me by said Richd Wittington this 4th July 1862.

To his Excellency B Magoffin.
Dear Sir

The undersigned have known Richd Whittington for a number of years, and can with propriety say that he is a quiet and orderly, law, abiding, and Moral citizen, and the affidavit above made by him we believe to be true, and we do most urgently beg your Excellency to remit the fine assessed agaisnt him for two hundred ^dollars^ at the last term of the Caldwell Circuit Court. We do believe he ought to be released from said penalty

R. W. Wake
F. N. Skinner
P D Yeiser
F A. Wilson
D B. Cassidy
D. W McGoodwin
C. Bennett
Jno H Roe
J W Bush
L Pepper
G. W. Barbour

I am satisfied that Mr Whittington was innocently drawn into it & without any intention of violating any law at the time Mr Whittington is a good citizen and regrets the occurence. & I know will not willingly violate the law, in any particular & earnestly recommend his case to the favourable consideration of your Excellency

Very Resp Tho. C. Dabry
